elements.name: ExistingFamilyCase
elements.title: Is there already a Family Law file open between the same parties in the Provincial Court of British Columbia?
elements.description: An open file could mean that documents have been filed at the courthouse but a judge may not have made an order yet.

elements.name: ExistingFamilyCaseFAQ1
elements.title: If I have a Family Law file open in the Supreme Court of British Columbia, should I include that?
elements.body: No, the file numbers are different between Provincial and Supreme Court. If you already have a Provincial Court file number, you will want to make sure that this document gets filed with the same file number.

elements.name: ExistingFamilyCaseFAQ2
elements.title: What if I already have a Family Law file open with different parties?
elements.body: If you have a Family Law file open with different parties, select no. You will need to open a new court file. You must follow the rules about which registry to use if you do not have an existing case with the same parties. The next questions will help you determine the correct court location, it may be the same one your case with other parties is already at.

elements.name: ExplanationExistingFamilyCase
elements.title: Note: You must file any new application at the court registry where your existing case is filed. If you need to apply for your protection order at another court registry, you must get the court’s permission. You can apply for this case management order by selecting the case management option in the first step of this service.

elements.name: ExplanationCourtLocation
elements.title:
You must file your application at the court location:
  • closest to where the child lives most of the time, if your case involves a child-related issue, or
  • closest to where you live, if your case does not involve a child-related issue
An application about a protection order can also be filed at another court location under special circumstances with the court’s permission.
Select the court location where you will be filing:

elements.name: CourtLocationFAQ1
elements.title: There is more than one close court location, how do I know which court location is closest?
elements.body: You can find a map of the court locations and addresses here. If two locations are both close, you can decide which is closest for filing your application. If the other party doesn’t agree, they can ask the court to transfer the file to the other location. It will then be up to the court to decide where the file is located.

elements.name: CourtLocationFAQ2
elements.title: What if the child lives equally in two different locations?
elements.body: If the child lives equally in two different locations closest to two different court locations, you will need to decide where you want to file your application. The rule about which court registry to use for filing an application is meant to ensure all applications are filed in the same registry and that the location is fair to the parties. Think about your family and which location is the most fair for everyone. If the other party doesn’t agree the registry you choose is the closest, they can ask the court to transfer the file to another location. It will then be up to the court to decide where the file is located.
